revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/APersonBot 8|Bot]] updating 2 categories with sort keys for an article about a battle
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=November 2015}} {{infobox military conflict |conflict = Battle of the Bell islands |partof = the [[American Theater (World War II)|American Theater]] and the [[Battle of the St. Lawrence]] of [[World War II]] |image = |caption = |date = August 1942 – November 1942 |place = [[Bell Island (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Bell Islands]], [[Newfoundland]] |coordinates = |result = Indecisive |combatant1 = {{flag|Canada|1921}}
{{flag|Newfoundland}} |combatant2 = {{flagcountry|Nazi Germany}} |commander1 = |commander2 = {{flagcountry|Nazi Germany}} [[Kapitän-Leutnant Rolf Ruggeberg]]
{{flagcountry|Nazi Germany}} [[Kapitän-Leutnant Friedrich Wissmann]]
{{flagcountry|Nazi Germany}} [[Werner von Janowski]] |strength1 = SS ''Lord Strathcona''
SS ''Saganaga''
SS ''Evelyn B''
SS ''Anna T''
''Flyingdale''
SS ''Rose Castle''
SS ''Caribou''
''PLM 27''
HMCS ''Drumheller''
2 Fairmile fast motor boats |strength2 = German U-boats
German submarine U-513
German submarine U-518 |casualties1 = SS ''Lord Strathcona'' (29 killed)
SS ''Saganaga''
SS ''Evelyn B''
SS ''Rose Castle'' (28 killed)
SS ''Caribou'' (137 killed)
''PLM 27'' (12 killed) |casualties2 = Spy captured |casualties3 = }} [[Bell Island (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Bell Island]] and [[Little Bell Island (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Little Bell Island]] are one of the few locations in North America that German forces directly attacked during the [[Second World War]]. [[U-boats]] raided the island twice in 1942, sinking four ore carriers and killing more than 60 men.{{Cite web|title = Bell Island Sinkings|url = http://www.heritage.nf.ca/articles/politics/bell-island-sinkings.php|website = www.heritage.nf.ca|accessdate = 2016-01-03}} The [[Sydney, Nova Scotia|Sydney]] to [[Channel-Port aux Basques|Port-aux-Basques]] passenger ferry [[SS Caribou]] was sunk in the Gulf of St. Lawrence with the loss of 136 people, including women and children, and four ore carriers were torpedoed at anchor at Wabana, Bell Island, killing 69 men.{{Cite web|url = http://www.seethesites.ca/designations/the-u-boat-attacks-on-the-bell-island-ore-ships-in-1942.aspx|title = U-Boat attacks on Bell Island 1942|accessdate = 2016-01-03|website = www.seethesites.ca}} It was later discovered that a spy was involved. On board U-518 was [[Werner von Janowski]], an agent of Germany’s [[Abwehr]] intelligence service. At the request of the [[Newfoundland]] Commission of Government, Canadian authorities developed defensive plans in case the Germans tried to capture [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1942|the Bell islands]] [[Category:1942 in Newfoundland]] [[Category:American Theater of World War II|the Bell islands]] {{WWII-stub}}
